Déjà vu is a psychological phenomenon characterized by the sensation that a current experience has been encountered before, despite the lack of evidence that it has. <[silence]> This effect is often accompanied by a strong sense of familiarity and the conviction that the situation is being repeated. <[silence]> It is a common occurrence, with studies indicating that approximately 60-80% of individuals report experiencing déjà vu at least once in their lifetime. <[silence]> The phenomenon is typically brief, lasting only a few seconds, and is more frequently reported among younger individuals. <[silence]>

The underlying mechanisms of déjà vu are not fully understood, but several theories have been proposed. <[silence]> One hypothesis suggests that déjà vu results from a temporary glitch in the brain's memory system, where new information is processed in a manner similar to the retrieval of stored memories. <[silence]> Another theory posits that déjà vu may occur when there is a misalignment between the brain's perception and memory systems, causing a false sense of recognition. <[silence]> Neuroimaging studies have implicated regions such as the temporal lobe and hippocampus in the experience of déjà vu, although definitive conclusions have yet to be reached. <[silence]>

Cognitive processes involved in déjà vu include recognition memory, which is the ability to identify previously encountered stimuli. <[silence]> The phenomenon may arise when there is an overlap between the familiarity of a current situation and the brain's memory trace of a similar past experience. <[silence]> This overlap can create a false impression of having lived through the exact same moment before. <[silence]> Additionally, déjà vu has been linked to attentional processes, where a brief distraction or lapse in focus may lead to the erroneous perception of familiarity. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are jamais vu, memory consolidation, and temporal lobe epilepsy. <[silence]>
